question: Where you going so early?
answer: Hey, don't record any more messages on my alarm--clock, okay?

question: Why not?
answer: I'll think we're married or something.

question: Don't you ever say that word. Or I'll never come over here and bring you chicken soup and fuck your brains out again.
answer: How's your cold?

question: Still there. How's yours?
answer: I guess you took my mind off it. She pulls a pink pill-box purse from the nightstand, withdraws a multi-colored phone.

question: Reyna, it's Julianna. I missed my audition. I lost my head. Listen, I have to go. I'm with David.
answer: Help yourself to whatever you want. Set the alarm, Maria will clean up. Lock up when you go. And... you are the greatest.

question: Bye "honey!"
answer: Bye "honey!" I'll call you later.

question: When? When?
answer: Soon! They have a comfortable, healthy, mutually satisfying, gloriously superficial relationship. Did you reserve the court?

question: Soon! They have a comfortable, healthy, mutually satisfying, gloriously superficial relationship. Did you reserve the court?
answer: Easy. I can't handle heavy conversation at this ungodly hour.

question: I'm sorry to do this early. I gotta be done by 10. Car phone rings. David checks Caller ID - it's his office. He clicks on. How did you find me? What are the colors? Let, me think about it. Okay, but. don't tell anybody where I am I don't care if God calls. I'm very busy.
answer: Can't you just get rid of that board?

question: The Seven Dwarves? No.
answer: Those people drive you nuts.

question: And that was the desire of my father, who hired them.
answer: You fucked Julie Gianni again, didn't you? David takes off driving. I know someone was there when I called. You had that tone. Oh, no man, I've got a cold. I'm hanging in tonight.

question: I had a cold. I was alone.
answer: Fine. You can do whatever you want with your life -

question: Thanks.
answer: -- but one day you'll know what love truly is. It's the sour and the sweet. And I know sour which allows me to appreciate the sweet.

question: Julie Gi.anni is a friend. Sometimes we sleep together. Brian howls in pain, like a hurt dog. What --
answer: My dream girl... Julie Gianni... is your... fuck buddy. Brian emits another pained howl. David reaches over to change the music.

question: What do you want to listen to?
answer: Slow down, man.

question: What have we got here - Barcelona, Looper... Radiohead? Brian freezes at what he sees.
answer: Look out! Look out! David turns and sees he's hurtling into the back of a car stopped just in front of him. Clenching he hits the brakes, narrowly avoiding a high-speech collision. And then... to his right... another car comes hurtling toward him... and stops within an inch of deadly impact. There is an awful moment, as the second car blares on the horn. Traffic continues, but the lingering feeling of dread and confusion is still in the air. Fuck!

question: We almost died.
answer: I know. My own death was right there in front of me, and you know what happened? Your life flashed before my eyes.

question: How was it?
answer: Almost worth dying for. Pedestrians continue walking around the honking tangled mass of the near-.accident.

question: You changed your hair. David taps on the window of the art department, in panic over several cover mock-ups. He gives a presidential thumbs-up, moves on. They look at each other, trying to decipher if the thumbs-up was a decision. Good. Now I want answers, and I want them now. How's it going? He gestures charmingly, easily, and bows with apology over his lateness. All are happy to see him. Sort of.
answer: You're scared of your dreams, aren't you?

question: It's a nightmare either way.
answer: Is that how do you explain what's happened to you?

question: What --
answer: What happened to your face?

question: I'm not talking to you anymore.
answer: And you don't want to show me your face.

question: No.
answer: Do you know why you're here?

question: The conversation, the coffee --
answer: David - the part where we parry and joust, and get to know each other bit-by-bit... we're going to have to skip it. You've been charged with murder. In four weeks, a judge will determine your fate based on what I write. You will talk to me --

question: There is no murder! It didn't happen! I don't have to talk to anybody! A Contentious Prison Guard swings his feet down and gets up from watching a 17-inch television on a stool. He exits into the bigger room to quiet down David Aames. Get the fuck away from me. Get the fuck away from me. My parents are dead, you fuck!
answer: Enough! The Contentious Guard leaves. Is it true?

question: Good cop... bad cop.
answer: That you're a Daddy's boy?

question: Primer on David Aames, Senior. My father was not built for the 21st Century. He never ate at
answer: I've read it. Page 127. "David Junior was a delight as a child." Did I miss something here? Is that all he wrote about you?

question: I don't think he ever got over the fact that I was terrified of heights. And when he and my mother were run over by a drunken teenager on New Year's Eve, ten years ago... David Aames moves closer to the light. We see a strange bland expression of his mask, at first other--worldly... and then more clearly. he left the keys to the Kingdom to me... 51% control, 49% going to a group of seven board members who all thought they were first in line.
answer: And you believe the Board, the Seven Dwarves, put you here to take control of your company.

question: What do you care?
answer: We're just talking. And tonight's Wednesday night, and I go to Black Angus for dinner with my daughters on Wednesday nights, so I'll have to leave soon. You understand that our time is limited, don't you?

question: If I talk, you'll just think I'm crazy. McCabe gathers his things.
answer: With all the respect I can offer a man wearing a latex mask and spouting conspiracy theories, David, trust me - you've crossed that bridge.

question: Fine. Enjoy your dinner. Somehow the lilt in McCabe's voice draws him closer.
answer: There are five basic emotions in life. Tell me. what emotion gripped... him... before he entered that cell? Was it Guilt? Shadows. There is no answer, just a rustling and a growing sense of anticipation in the darkness. Hate? Shame? Shadows. Still no answer. Revenge... McCabe now shows the invisible skill with which he has brought his client to the precipice. And now, with one word, he invites David Aames to look over. Love? In the darkness, a rustling and the slight turn of a head. I'm completely on the wrong track, aren't I?

question: Who needs ice? Aames moves swirls is more like it - through into his party, which is nicely underway. Upscale. Modern. Part literary crowd. Part fashion crowd. He's great in a crowd. Surrounded by people, David Aames comes alive. Jesus, you have the greatest taste in shoes I've ever seen. Bar none. Anywhere. A Woman Caterer in Whites slips by with a knowing smile. Emma, do you know Lynette?
answer: Hey man. Happy birthday and all the usual shit people say to each other. How you doing?

question: Livin' the dream, baby. Livin' the dream. The two friends hug. David shares a quick glance with Brian's date, who still burdened with coat.
answer: Meet David Aames.

question: I'll leave this upstairs. David exits. They are left to consider his personal charisma. Hey Tommy. David moves to address him so he can still track Sofia.
answer: Hey. Listen to me. Don't blow me off. I'm all packed, I'm going back to London and I understand. You put me up for that other attorney's job, so you didn't have to fire me. A classy move, and your father would have done the same ---

question: It's okay, Tommy --
answer: I became incompetent. Is there anything more unbecoming than an aging mascot? I cared about your father. I lived and breathed for him. But these guys, the board, they think you're stupid. A corporate hazard, a rogue. But the word "stupid" is what David heard loudest of all. Nearby, we see a Woman Partner taking a quick look at David. But they're going to find a way to get you out. They're lined up for your office - David scans the room. Beneath the good cheer, he sees the other layer. Lying. Disloyalty. All part of the institution he enjoys forgetting exists. Each word bashes his soul. -- your job. Your life. Your position. They are working day and night. to cheat you out of your 51% vote. And they are going to sell this tradition, this tradition of words, so they can eat at a better cafeteria. And what they don't know is this - - people will read again. David's gaze falls upon Sofia, who is looking directly at him. And for one blinding moment, something passes between them. She looks away. He feels saved.

question: I got it.
answer: They even have a nickname for you behind your back. David smiles faintly. Understandingly. Tipp kisses him on the cheek, boldly and drunkenly. He feels like a hero to himself. Citizen Dildo. David flinches, just a little. Now you've got great instincts. But I say this with complete love. Claim your life... Learn to be an Asshole... Don't be -

question: Two's enough -
answer: Don ' t be- Okay. Forgive me. I still believe in this family. Even if it's only you. David continues tracking Sofia as he slips over to Peter Brown.

question: Get Tipp out of here, drive him home, and in the morning tell him he's re-hired with a 50% raise. Set up a meeting with the other attorneys. I'm going to be in early tomorrow -- -- earlier than usual.
answer: Hello handsome. He turns to see Julie Gianni in the bathroom doorway, wrapped in a comforter. I've come to wish you happy birthday.

question: I didn't invite you, Julie.
answer: Yeah, that was a little weird -

question: But that's how it works with parties. You have to be invited.
answer: I'm mad at you, you dick. We made love four times the other night.

question: Is that good?
answer: Two is good. Three is very good. But four -

question: Four is pretty good?
answer: No, four is... four is... just hold me.

question: Four is what?
answer: Hold me, and then I'll leave, and you can go talk to that cute brunette.

question: Four is what?
answer: I don't want to meet your fancy friends. I knew 'em all back when I was fancy too. He holds her. They talk in between friendly kisses.

question: Four is what? She pulls away, and talks plainly to him.
answer: She looks like a moth, David.

question: A moth?
answer: Sometimes I worry about one of these clever girls in a big silly coat who'll play you in just the right way, and I'll lose my friend. And there'll be no more chicken soup parties for you and me. When will you call me? And don't say soon. I hate it when you say "soon."

question: So this is what's become of rock and roll. A smashed guitar behind a glass case displayed on some rich guy's wall.
answer: It was a gift, actually. She turns and sees it's David, engaging smile in place. She jumps slightly.

question: I like it. She turns and walks away, David following close behind.
answer: Whoa, whoa, whoa.

question: - how did you get all this stuff, this apartment, this life - David is looking just over her shoulder. She turns to see an almost disturbingly large portrait of David Aames, Sr. She turns back. I see.
answer: How about if you help me? Unless I'm horning in here.

question: You are, but the food's good.
answer: See, I've got a little problem. I've got a stalker.

question: It doesn't. sound life-threatening. Someone passes, bumping her slightly, into him.
answer: I need a cover. I need for you to pretend we're having a scintillating conversation. And you're wildly entertained. I know it's tough.

question: I'll improvise -
answer: She's right across the room and she's burning a hole in my back right now, isn't she?

question: Red dress, strappy shoes?
answer: Yes_

question: -- wow, she's really staring at you.
answer: Shit.

question: And she seems to be growing... less happy.
answer: Hmm.

question: I think she's the saddest girl to ever hold a martini. Julie Gianni sits on the steps watching. The girl, and the dress, looked much happier in the bedroom. Julie rises and begins to move. You have another apartment?
answer: Sort of a day office. Come on - They arrive at the door to a smaller upstairs apartment.

question: I'm not going in there.
answer: Well I am. Goodnight. He enters and shuts the door. Frustrated, she stands for a moment, listening to the music streaming from the downstairs apartment. We watch her private moment as she decides to leave him, turns, feels the emotional pull, dances back and knocks sharply three times.

question: I hear her coming. No. David pulls her inside. Shuts the door behind them.
answer: We're safe. And I've got nothing to drink...

question: Who did these paintings?
answer: This is Joni Mitchell. This one is Monet. And this one is done by me. It is a snowboard.

question: Well, two of them are geniuses.
answer: It's the real thing. His paintbrush painted that vanilla sky. His canvas. It. was my mother's. You know what I think? You're either a very good actress or you really do sort of like me.

question: I am an actress.
answer: There's probably not too much you aren't great at.

question: Are you about to compliment, my phone voice?
answer: It's pretty good, you know -

question: Oh, I'd only disappoint, you. See - I'm not. qualified. I can spell.
answer: I'm surprised you're available.

question: I'm surprised you're surprised.
answer: I can't keep this banter going.

question: Nobody stalks me. So I drink.
answer: Well, we're out of drinks up here.

question: Here, finish my Jack and Coke. He messily tries to hand his drink to David, but spills it embarrassingly. All his cool is gone, and what's left are his friends covering for him, cleaning up.
answer: These stupid glasses -

question: I better hit it. I drank too much and I didn't fucking eat.
answer: Don't be stupid. The party's just starting.

question: For you it is.
answer: You can't go. You're my guest of honor.

question: Fuck you, David. You're paying me to write my novel, so you own me.
answer: I don't own you. You're brilliant, you're good-looking, you're handsome.

question: But why'd you have to hit on Sofia?
answer: No one's hitting on Sofia.

question: Fine. Whatever you say. I'm crazy, I'm blind.
answer: No, you're not blind. You're just drinking Jack Daniels. And when you drink Jack, you start. in with that Frank Sinatra, "She Shot. Me Down," gimme a cigarette, King of Sad thing...

question: That. I do. Gimme a cigarette.
answer: I'll find one.

question: But wait. You're rich and women love you and I'm from Ohio and I'm drunk. Can I tell you the truth?
answer: Everyone does.

question: I dig her. And I've never said this to you before, about any girl. But she could be... could be could be could be... the girl of my fuckin dreams.
answer: You're not from Ohio.

question: I know. But if she fucks tip our friendship - she can go to hell. I won't allow it! We are bros.
answer: I feel the same way.

question: Sure you do. Brianprepares to leave, as Sofia returns with drinks.
answer: Where you going?

question: I am Frank. And Frank must go.
answer: Huh?

question: I good you bid evening. Sofialooks at her watch, and the situation.
answer: Hang on, I'll go with you.

question: The Sweet and Sour speech again. A lot of people are scared of heights. It's not the heights that bother me, it's the impact that terrifies me. I won't stay long. She laughs. It was never his decision to make.
answer: Hey Paulo! A large goofy dog comes running at her, and then proceeds to slather David with love too.

question: I'm glad he protects you. This is a lethal canine.
answer: I love living here. And I refuse to clean up!

question: No problem.
answer: I've got to work around the clock to keep this place. David eases the dog away as he examines the oddly exquisite dolls. He grabs a look at her in the other room. A bit of leg between boot and skirt. As he admires the dolls:

question: So you're really a dancer, huh?
answer: For 14 years. But I don't dance like you dance. She laughs to herself, steals a look at him. Turns away. Do you want something to drink?

question: Sure. David looks at her refrigerator. A note reads I like your life.
answer: Well, it's mine and you can't have it. David examines a humorously embarrassing vacation photo of a sloshed Sofia, a guy's arm reaching for her breast. Dedication reads

question: I do not want to know the story behind this photo. Who's Sergio?
answer: It's a nickname.

question: Your nickname is Sergio?
answer: It's a long story, and we don't know each other.

question: So many secrets.
answer: That's because I'm really an arms dealer.

question: I've never known an arms dealer.
answer: You do now. What about you? What's your nickname? David freezes. And then decides what the hell - to tell the truth.

question: Citizen Dildo.
answer: You're not staying over.

question: Never run a company. Stay an artist. Stay an arms dealer.
answer: Oh please. Somehow, I can't play the violin for you. Although. It must be hard controlling all those people's lives. Everyone at that party is connected to you for survival in some way, it seems. David looks at her, mentally assessing her level of guile. Ever been married?

question: No. Ever accept any of your 12,000 proposals?
And you moved to New York. To dance and paint and act and deal arms.
answer: Right. Do you want to hear Jeff Buckley... or Vikki Carr?

question: Jeff Buckley... or Vikki Carr? Both - simultaneously. He continues looking. Flashes of the photos on her refrigerator.
answer: Everyone said "don't go to New York." But I just think good You think I'm naive. He decides she's for real. He turns back to the photos on her fridge.

question: No. I really don't.
answer: I have to get to sleep. Truthfully -- I'm also working mornings as a dental assistant.

question: Boy, am I going to the wrong dentist.
answer: How does that work? - actually no I don't. I've been married for twenty-two years.

question: Ah, you've got dinner with your daughters.
answer: That's right. I do.

question: Back then I had intricate systems with women you wouldn't believe.
answer: Like... what...

question: Hey Doc. Don't get all melancholy over the thirty seconds you were single a long time ago.
answer: That's what you think I'm doing?

question: Yes.
answer: Well, you may have a point. Let's continue. Time is not our friend.

question: Just our shortcomings. That's all we're allowed to draw.
answer: I've never drawn such a true likeness before.

question: Mine's finished.
answer: Already? Hang on. Okay - done. Sofia offers her drawing. It's a caricature of a good- looking guy surrounded by money, cars and very thin girls. He snatches it, studies it, and what he sees hurts him in surprising ways.

question: Jesus. That's how you see me?
answer: Maybe I didn't add enough money --

question: No. It's wonderful. It's something you'd see on the wall of a steak-house in hell, but it's wonderful. Sign it. Sofia's face falls a bit. She sees she's hurt him. She takes the drawing and signs it, a little guilty.
answer: Let's see yours.

question: No. She grabs it. Its a rich portrait, filled with detail, humor and style. She is rocked by its elegance.
answer: Wow. I feel bad. You said to draw a caricature.

question: I know. I couldn't. I saw you like that.
answer: Well, it's very good.

question: I'll sell it to you.
answer: You monster. How much for?

question: One kiss. She smiles. Something is developing between them. That smile is gonna be the end of me.
answer: And what happens when your friend calls you tomorrow?

question: He only met you a few hours before me. He would do the same.
answer: I see that friendship is important to you.

question: It is. But as his best friend, I also know that he's trying to finish a novel about inadequacy and rejection. So the longer I stay, the better it is for his career. Sofia smiles, shakes her head. And yawns.
answer: Your career is one I'd worry about. David looks down. She's hit a nerve. I'm sorry -

question: No, no. You're more right then you even know. I used to be one of those guys who was just
answer: When did you change?

question: About five minutes ago.
answer: Every passing minute is another chance to turn it all around. David shakes his head a little. Her words strike right to the heart of him. What are you watching?

question: It's the greatest show... it's called "Sofia." Sofia looks at him and smiles. They look back to the television.
answer: I've seen this thirty times.

question: We did a story on this guy. He owns half of Arizona.
answer: Is he a fraud?

question: How would you ever know?
answer: Good point. Oh, well that's comforting. It's safe for Benny. I'm in! David moves closer to her. We better watch out. They regard each other, and David gets up off the sofa. It's true. The promise is too great to not savor it, and walk away for now. Thrill remains in the air. Where are you going?

question: I left my number on your fridge. He makes a courtly bow and turns. She feels the loss of his company.
answer: Come here, I want to tell you a secret. He pauses a moment, and turns. In this instant, a fleeting instant, it's the oddest thing. He can see their entire I meant that to be your forehead. David stands. He looks around the small apartment.

question: Thank you for the inspiration. I will now attempt to run my company, showing compassion for the seething throng of my partners who root quietly for me to fail. She looks at him, quite aware of his personal and business crossroads. Silently, she roots for him like crazy. For things you don't even know - thank you. I'm going to go to work. I have a company to run.
answer: Pleasure delayer. He is still somewhat stunned by the evening, and the girl. He actually wants to run his company.

question: David Aames. David leans on his car, turns and shakes his head.
answer: Julie Gianni. You're following me.

question: only a little. I wanted to finish what we were talking about.
answer: And _- Yes she did.

question: But I can see from your walk that you didn't sleep with her. David turns. Let me see if I can guess. You haven't slept with her because... it's more fun when you can draw it out. Sex just isn't as good if the woman hasn't told all her friends she'd never sleep with you.
answer: You're right on the money, Julie.

question: She must be exhausted from trying to be witty for you all night long.
answer: Hey, Julie. I'm not blowing you off! I just want to be alone for a little bit. Trust me - I have a lot of things I gotta take care of. If we're friends, which we are, you'll understand.

question: I'm sorry I got weird. I missed an audition and I just felt bad Do you want to make it up to me? I won't tell a soul. Slowly, he is drawn to her. His old self rallies one last time. He gets in the car. Would you do a story about me if I made a CD?
answer: Sure I would -

question: Do you like my music?
answer: It's vivid.

question: If I weren't me, I would buy a CD by me.
answer: Well, you know, if you can reach one person. Julianna is a little hurt, hides it well.

question: What is happiness to you, David?
answer: what is happiness?

question: For me, this is happiness. Being with you. David doesn't look at her. She speeds up, slowly.
answer: I didn't tell him that. I didn't say that.

question: When did you stop caring?
answer: About what --

question: About the consequences of the promises you made.
answer: Promises - I thought we had an understanding.

question: Do you know how hard it is to pretend to be your "buddy?" I love you, David. You fucked me four times in one night. You have been inside me and I have swallowed your come. That means something.
answer: Julie...

question: Four times, David! That means something. Four times. He grabs at the wheel. She won't let go, and speeds up.
answer: stop the car! She picks at things on the dashboard, as she talks with a manic energy.

question: Twenty-four hours a day I live with the aching possibility that you might call me to do something.
answer: Take me to your house. We'll talk this out. I want to see where you live. I want you to stop the car, Julie. I want you to stop the car!

question: Hello. He steals a kiss. They both feel like they're getting away with something.
answer: You're amazing. Hello.

question: Did you get to work alright?
answer: Yeah, well, actually... I had a horrible dream.

question: You dreamed you'd never see me again.
answer: I left your house. I went to the car, and my friend the stalker had been following me.

question: Julie.
answer: Yes. She followed me down the street. She wanted to talk, and I had that buzz... from you and me, and I think my mind was on that terrible drawing of me... and, you know, I got inside. And she drove me off a bridge and committed suicide with me in the car.

question: I thought you were going straight to work.
answer: But I survive! I survive with my arm and my face reconstructed. And what's worse I couldn't wake up.

question: How was your house after the party?
answer: What party? A party?

question: The PARTY. Remember? Red dress... strappy shoes... I spilled something on your SHIRT... sweet and sour... and the saddest girl to ever hold a martini. He looks at her, completely lost and spacy.
answer: I don't... I don't remember.

question: I don't... I don't remember.
answer: Do you dream about the car accident?

question: And then... I came back to life. Just like that dog, Benny. Benny The Dog.
answer: Benny. Benny The Dog.

question: Except my life was no longer normal. There were blinding migranes now... . nerve damage. Why? This is how big business operates. A random accident. A "lifestyle mishap?" They are not coincidences. How do you think air-tight contracts are broken? These are power upheavals.
answer: I'm from Ohio - we don't have power upheavals.

question: Yes, well, the rumors of my death have been mildly exaggerated.
answer: The cranial structure was based on thirty pins fastened by small panels and bits of bone from the mandible... and it seems the cartilage grafts have maintained your cheek structure. Unfortunately, because you were in a coma, immediate plastic surgery was impossible.

question: Is that the procedure for all Bilateral Periorbital Hematomas in a LeFort III fracture of a comatose patient?
answer: In a LeFort III - absolutely. The potential for sub-cranial brain damage was too great.

question: And beyond the cheek grafts, Dr. Pomeranz is, are the pins fastened
answer: Yes, we are working on processes. But it... you're specifically not at the stage where we can experiment --

question: Experiment. Use me.
answer: The headaches will go away -

question: These are more than headaches. This is like a steel plate slicing through my every thought.
answer: We're not cowboys. We can't, just wing it.

question: Because I can't think straight most of the time.
answer: We can increase your medication.

question: Yes. Medication.
answer: And there are things we'll continue to investigate. But there are so many others who've not been able to benefit aesthetically from plastic surgery as you have --

question: This isn't about vanity, Dr. Pomeranz! This isn't about vanity. This is about functioning in the world. Fuck my arm! Dr. Pomeranz looks over to a young assistant.
answer: Nobody here takes your feelings for granted. We did prepare something for you, based on the preliminary examination.

question: Tell me. Bring it on.
answer: It's sometimes useful in the early stages of rejection. It's a facial prosthetic. It was two weeks in the making. The assistant opens a black-leather bound box. In it is the mask - molded from David's own face, locked into a pleasant, bland expression.

question: A facial prosthetic.
answer: The aesthetic replacement does work. Emotionally, and actually.

question: So it's an aesthetic regenerative shield.
answer: That's correct. Exactly.

question: I see --
answer: It's a helpful unit.

question: Good. Because for a minute there I thought we were talking about a fucking mask!

question: No it's great. This completely takes care of Halloween. But what about the other 364 days of the year? Sofia. Sofia. Sofia. Sofia. Sofia. Sofia. because nobody's buying books let's invest... my father was an adventurer. Sofiaaaaaaaaaaa. Serrano. You won't believe this... but this is me smiling. She laughs a little at his strange new humor, keeps a brave front.
answer: It's been a long time. I tried to see you but your people wouldn't let me.

question: I didn't want to see me, okay. But then I woke up today and finally, a good hair day. David fights anxiety, smoothes his coat. You want to go out, you want to do something?
answer: Sure.

question: What?
answer: Let's go out and do something.

question: This weekend. I'll cancel an operation or two. We'll have fun. Because I am all about fun. She kisses his cheek, pulls back quickly, and as she exits... he sees her fighting tears. Hey listen, it's David. I'm back in your life. I saw you earlier tonight. I was just watching our old friend Benny the Dog on... on Conan... and I thought of you. Whatever. I loved seeing you today. So I'll see you soon. You're a great dancer! He hangs up and feels instantly mortified. He looks at the phone in his hand.
answer: Hi!

question: Behind... over by the place next to the door by the chick... I mean, girl who looks like Bjork. She leaves. David turns to Brian immediately.
answer: You look good, man. How's your book?

question: Take it off.
answer: I can't. It's a facial shield. It's an antiseptic prosthesis to stop infections. These fucking doctors.

question: Take off the mask! It's freaking me out.
answer: I can't. It's my face. This is my face.

question: Oh no. Trust me. It's a little different.
answer: Hey, if you're embarrassed, just go. Nobody asked you to chaperone

question: Sofia asked me.
answer: She didn't want to be alone with me? That's bullshit. Because I think I'm being pretty fucking cool about the whole thing.
